Award.AwardTitle: Early Grant in Exploratory Research: Acquisition and analysis of sediment cores from the eastern tropical Indian Ocean
Award.AbstractNarration:
The dynamics of the tropical Indian Ocean represent a major wildcard in the projections of many large-scale aspects of the climate system. In principle, the strength of the South Asian monsoon, the inter-ocean linkages of interannual-centennial variability throughout the tropics, and the expression of greenhouse gas induced warming of the upper ocean must all be influenced by, or mediated through the tropical thermocline. Despite its importance, there are a number of first order questions about the dynamics and variability in this system that remain unanswered.

The primary objective of this work is to collect and analyze sediment cores from an under-sampled region with the eventual goal of resolving the mid- to upper tropical Indian Ocean dynamics over ice age cycles. The project takes advantage of a student training expedition that will focus primarily on geophysical mapping of the Sunda Arc, but also allow ample time for surveying and gravity coring of nearby areas. Follow-on work will include laboratory-based analysis of the those sediment cores to establish
stratigraphic context and to test the potential of new methods (e.g., individual foraminiferal analysis) for addressing the overall objectives of the project.

The primary broader impact of this project lies in the exceptional opportunity for heuristic student training in oceanographic sample and data collection. Students will experience the sediment coring process from start to finish--from the strategic design of the cruise plan, through the shipboard execution of gravity coring, and ultimately to the scientific applications. The outcomes of the coring and surveys will also provide the basis for larger basin-wide initiatives to study long-timescale tropical climate change.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit: The scientific goals of this project were firstly, to survey for, and to retrieve multiple deep sea sediment cores from a key--and, as yet sparsely sampled--region in the Indian Ocean that might record the variable influence of the Indonesian Throughflow influence over the last ice age cycle. This objective was severely (and negatively) affected by the fact that diplomatic clearances to collect sediment cores within the Indonesian EEZ were never granted, despite assurances to the contrary prior to the cruise. Consequently, the experimental plan was adjusted in real time, and a much less promising region along the Ninenty East Ridge was surveyed and cored. Analysis of the sediment cores collected suggested very low accumulation rate, which rendered them unsuitable for paleoceanographic study. A subsequent objective was to conduct conduct a "proof of concept" study involving the isotopic analyses of single specimens of foraminifera extracted from the collected sediment cores. The idea is that, because each specimen lived for approximately two weeks, its isotopic and chemical composition reflects a single snapshot of ocean conditions during the time of growth. Though specimens whose time of growth spans several thousand years are mixed together in any sample of a typical deep sea sediment core,  the population statistics of individual specimen allow a means for reconstruction the seasonal-centennial variance in the upper tropical Indian Ocean across the last ice age.  Though the sediment cores collected as part of this project were not suitable for this objective, individual foraminifera were analysed in a previously-collected core "downstream" of the Indonesian Throughflow in the western Indian Ocean. The results suggest that the structure of the upper ocean indeed responded to the global climate changes of the last ice age cycle, including the strength of the Southwest Indian Monsoon system.

Broader Impacts: The educational goals of this project were primarily to provide first hand (leadership training) experience in all aspects of marine sediment survey and coring for graduate students. Two students (Riley Gannon and Alan Foreman) planned for, and carried out all phases of the coring effort.  Effectively, these students were co chief scientists aboard the R/V Revelle. As a result of these first hand experiences, these students are now eminently qualified to serve as P.I.'s for future sediment coring cruises.A secondary educational goal was to use the cruise activities as a pedagogical platform for the marine sediment component of a graduate level SIO course in marine geology (serving 20 and 16 students in 2014 and 2015). The shipboard participants conducted a near real time question and answer session while aboard ship in 2014, and the class members in 2014 and 2015 then examined the cores collected.
